description: Given an array of integers representing encoded words, count the number of pairs (i, j) where i < j such that nums[j] is a Caesar cipher shift of nums[i] by some fixed shift amount applied to all digits.

testCases.explanation: All pairs are Caesar cipher shifts of each other with shift 11 (mod 10 on each digit). (11,22) ✓ (11,33) ✓ (22,33) ✓. Count=3.
No two numbers form a valid Caesar cipher pair (different digit shift patterns). Count=0.
12 and 34 share a shift of 2 on each digit (1+2=3, 2+2=4). One pair. Count=1.
Both numbers are identical, which is a Caesar cipher with shift 0. Count=1.
13 and 57 differ by shift 4 per digit (1+4=5, 3+4=7 mod 10). 57 and 24 differ by a non-uniform shift. Only (13,57) is a valid Caesar cipher pair. Count=1.
